awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Diversifying Human-Centered Data Science through the Research and Design of Ethical Games
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). Tackling the overwhelming issues in data science and machine learning require new ways of training and combining expertise from social science, human-centered design, information studies, statistics, computer science, and related fields. We invite interested undergraduates across disciplines to collaborate on the research and design of a serious game on data ethics issues. In this context, our project studies collaborative learning in groups of peers with conflicting methodological cultures and diverse backgrounds. Participating students will come from two university campuses in different regions of the United States to form a single team of diverse individuals collaborating in a virtual setting. By studying students’ experiences throughout the project, we will increase our understanding of learning through collaboration over time and in relation to their sociocultural histories. An additional artifact of this two-year, interdisciplinary project will be a prototype of an educational game, targeted towards the underrepresented communities and the greater public, that will bring more people into critical conversations about the roles of AI and data science in our society.

The primary aim of our research is the production of novel theories in learning sciences regarding collaborative learning in the face of diverse backgrounds and cultural norms. How do students individually and collectively position themselves within data ethics and do these views change over time with increased exposure to technical concepts and norms? How do students reconcile conflicting norms in the design of a single design project? Does the collaborative design of an ethical simulation game facilitate diverse student learning experiences? Our work will be conducted as an ethnographic case study with analysis heavily informed by sociocultural-historical theory. Multiple streams of data will be collected over the course of the project, including observations in the “field,” i.e. of the team meetings (consisting of both audiovisual recordings and researchers’ field notes), informal conversations with participants, products created by the team (such as papers, images, prototypes, etc), brief surveys, and participant interviews. This work aims to contribute new theories on collaborative learning to the body of research in learning sciences as well as serve as a case study for future educational projects situated between disciplines with conflicting cultural norms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Our project focused on the research and design of ethical data science games with three major goals, all of which were accomplished within the two-year timeframe.

First, undergraduates across disciplines collaborated on the research and design of a serious game on data ethics issues. Participating students came from two university campuses in different regions of the United States (Texas and Washington state) to form a single team of diverse individuals, supervised by PhD students and faculty and connected via internet technologies. By studying students’ experiences throughout the project, we increased our understanding of learning through collaboration in interdisciplinary and geographically distributed teams and in areas of conflicting norms. This model of research collaboration allowed for the creation of new knowledge that took into account a wide range of perspectives.

Second, it brought together a senior faculty researcher from the University of Washington (UW) with an early career data science researcher at the same institution and a junior faculty member at the University of North Texas (UNT), a designated Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI). Through this collaborative team of women, two of whom come from communities that are underrepresented in STEM, we worked to increase high-quality research with diverse participation. This led to increased research opportunities for an interdisciplinary and geographically diverse student body.

Third, we produced multiple game prototypes (see Figures 1-4 below), and converged on a game that has brought students into critical conversations about the roles of AI and data science in our society. The game is a collaborative multiplayer game that consists of understanding a realistic data science problem, testing models, interpreting statistical results, and determining ethical and social challenges that may arise.

Broader Impacts

Outreach has included advertising the program and goals throughout the two institutions to a multidisciplinary audience. For example, outreach has been made to leaders of relevant student groups on campus. This has led to the interest of several students who were previously unaware of research activities on campus. We have additionally published 1 journal article, 3 long conference papers, 1 conference poster, and 1 workshop paper, for a total of 5 publications. We created two explanatory websites, one at each university. We produced a data science ethics curriculum that is freely available to the public.

This project impacted the field of the learning sciences by offering a novel approach to learning through game design via our directed research group model. During this process, students created several game prototypes demonstrating a range of topics that can be addressed in serious games. Information about both the educational approach and the prototypes have been disseminated through academic products.

Our findings have also made an impact on human-centered design, data science, artificial intelligence, and machine learning disciplines by introducing experiential approaches in simulation-based data science methodology as well as the introduction of novel educational experiences regarding ethical and societal issues in data science.

The project allowed for training and professional development at several different levels. One first year graduate student worked one-on-one with PI Herman in the design and development of the curriculum in the form of a teaching practicum. Four other PhD students were mentored in the research techniques needed for the project, working with the PIs to conduct research and disseminate their results through publication. Further, the many Masters students and advanced undergraduates in the research project were all introduced to research design in depth with the goal of preparing these students for the future.

Finally, the combination of a more senior PI with two more junior PIs led to training and professional development opportunities within the investigators themselves.
